questions.text: All are treatment modalities for sudden sensorineural hearing loss except:
questions.solution:
The most common treatment modalities for ISSHL are one or more of the following: systemic steroids (SSs), intratympanic steroid injection (ITSI), hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HOT), antiviral drugs, and vasodilators or vasoactive substances.

Some cases will improve spontaneously. Transdermal nitroglycerin patch along with pulse steroid injections are the most recent form of treatment being studied and may provide hope for these patients, despite of the rarity and the unpredictable natural history of the disorder.

questions.text: Identify the area marked with the arrow?
What is the wavelength of CO2 laser?
questions.solution: The CO2 laser emits invisible infrared light at a wavelength of 10,600 nm in the infrared range of the electromagnetic spectrum, and the light cannot be seen by the human eye. Carbon-dioxide (CO2) lasers are powerful and comparatively efficient gas lasers emitting at 10.6 µm or at other wavelengths around 9-11 µm. A gas discharge excites nitrogen molecules, which transfer their energy to the laser-active CO2 molecules.

questions.text: What is the function of the Laryngeal muscle shown with arrows ?
questions.solution: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles extend from the oval depressions on the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina on each side and extend upward to the muscular process of the arytenoid cartilage on the same side.  These muscles function to rotate the arytenoid cartilages laterally, thereby abducting the vocal cords

questions.text: All of the the following are differential diagnosis in the audiogram shown except?
questions.solution: Audiograms are performed at different points during the course or progression of disease, and the hearing loss shows a fluctuating pattern. During the initial stages of the disease, if the PTA is performed after an episode has subsided, the audiogram may look to be normal.

questions.text: Which of the following tuning fork test is used to check Malingering ?
questions.solution: The Stenger test is based on the auditory phenomenon “The Stenger Principle” and is used when a patient is suspected malingering a hearing loss. The Stenger Principle states that only the louder of two similar tones presented to both ears at the same time will be perceived.

choices.text: ASOM with high conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: All are indications of Myringotomy except?
questions.solution:
A myringotomy, sometimes called by other names, is a surgical procedure in which a tiny incision is created in the eardrum (tympanic membrane) to relieve pressure caused by excessive buildup of fluid, or to drain pus from the middle ear.

Incision types

Myringotomy is usually performed as an outpatient procedure.

Cutting type: given in posterior inferior quadrant, this is done in cases of acute otitis media.

Splitting type: given in anterior inferior quadrant, this is done in cases of serious otitis media ('glue ear'), this type of incision is suitable for grommet insertion.

Incision is either 'j'(hockey) shaped or curvilinear shaped and it is given from below upward so as to ease the drainage

A myringotomy may be done: To restore hearing loss caused by chronic fluid build-up and to prevent delayed speech development caused by hearing loss in children. To place tympanostomy tubes — these tubes help to equalize pressure.

questions.text: Which is the most preferred modality of treatment for recurrent respiratory papillomatosis?
questions.solution:
The current standard of care for the management of RRP is surgical excision. Objectives of surgery are to preserve adequate voice quality and airway patency.36 Complete eradication is not necessarily the goal, as HPV is believed to remain dormant in laryngeal epithelial cells whether active papilloma is visible or not. More extensive excision of papilloma from sites that are not contributing to airway or voice?related goals has not been shown to reduce recurrence rates.37 In fact, aggressive resection may be counter?productive, in that injury to the mucosal surface has been associated with increased expression of HPV in nearby HPV?infected cells.

In addition,two pilot studies showed preliminary evidencefor post? excision,office? based,intralesional administration of the adjuvants bevacizumab and cidofovir improving the outcome

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the hospital with a compressible swelling at the root of nose, see the clinical picture below, most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• 2 years child with compressible swelling at the root of nose is likely Meningoencephalocele
  • Lacrimal sac cyst occurs as a compressible swelling near the medical canthus
  • Ethmoid cyst (mucocele) present as a swelling at the medical quadrant of orbit pushing the orbit forwards and laterally (also see the chapter on sinusitis)
  • AV malformation is a congenital abnormal connection between arteries and veins, bypassing the capillary system. These are largely found in internal organs most commonly brain. It is rare at this site.

questions.text: Direction of nasolacrimal dust is
Maxillary sinus achieves maximum size at:

choices.text: Optic nerve and floor of orbit
Optic nerve and ethmoids air cells

questions.text: Onodi cells and Haller cells are seen in relation to:
True about rhinophyma
Depressed bridge of the nose may be due to any of the following except
questions.solution: • Acromegaly occurring due to growth hormone secreting pituitary adenoma is characterised by enlargement of the nose

questions.text: Feature associated with DNS Include all of the following except:
questions.solution: • There is no pressure atrophy of the turbinates on the side of deviation of septum. In DNS there occurs hypertrophy of turbinate of opposite

questions.text: Improvement in nasal patency by retracting the lateral part of the cheek and thus testing the valvular component of the nose is:
questions.solution:
• Epley's manoeuvre is the repositioning manoeuvre done for the management of BPPV (benign paroxysmal positional vertigo)
  • Heimlich manoeuvre is the initial immediate management of accidental inhalation of foreign body. In Heimlich manoeuvre multiple thrusts are given with the wrist in the upper epigastrium while standing behind the patient
  • There is no Schwartz manoeuvre

questions.text: Unilateral proptosis and bilateral 6th nerve palsy is seen in
questions.solution:
• In this patient the cavernous sinus of the other side has started getting involved leading to the 6th nerve palsy. Bilateral proptosis will soon follow
  • Meningitis and hydrocephalus do not lead to proptosis through both of then can involve B/L 6th nerve involvement (this being the most common nerve involved in CNS pathologies)

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a long history of purulent nasal discharge now presents with fever and right sided conjunctival congestion and edema for the past 3 days, see picture below. His fever is 1020 F and WBC count is 12000µL. The culture of eye discharge was negative. Xray shows opacification of ethmoid sinus. Which of the following should be the next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution: • The child has probably developed orbital cellulitis or orbital abscess following ethmoid sinusitis for which a CT scan should be done. CT scan will differentiated orbital cellulitis from orbital cellulitis from orbital abscess and also helps to see the extent of involvement of sinuses. In case of orbital cellulitis, after initial stabilisation with antibiotics, FESS should be performed late on for chronic sinusitis. If orbital abscess in there it will require antibiotics with orbital decompression and FESS

questions.text: To reduce synechiae formation after nasal surgery which one of the following packing is most useful:
questions.solution:
• Mitomycin C is an antineoplastic agent with ant fibroblastic activity. It is used to decrease the chances of adhesions and fibrosis following surgery.
  • In ENT it is used in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) (as any adhesion between the middle meatus and lateral wall of nose will again block the drainage of sinuses), after correction of choanal atresia and laryngotracheal stenosis (as any fibrosis or adhesion of this area will lead to re stenosis leading to stridor)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with history of nasal blockade for 6 months. On examination, the patient had a nasal mass with mucin discharge. What is the probable diagnosis based on the CT scan:
questions.solution:
• The NCCT shows haziness of the maxillary sinus and mass in the left nasal cavity without any bony erosion
  • Fungal sinusitis presents as U/L nasal mass (ployp) with mucinous discharge in adults. Antrochonal polpy is seen in young as U/L nasal mass, patient presents here mainly with nasal obstruction, discharge if at all present is purulent and not mucinous. Ethmoidal polyps are B/L. Maxillary carcinomas is U/L nasal mass, presenting with blood tinged nasal discharge, CT here shows bony erosion

questions.text: Recurrent polypi are seen in:
questions.solution:
• As the ethmoidal polyps are allergic in etiology they are highly recurrent
  • Antrochoanal polyp can also recur through their recurrence is uncommon
  • Concha bullosa is pneumatised middle turbinate. It does not recur after surgical correction
  • Hypertrophic turbinate also does not recur after turbinectomy

questions.text: A child presented with history of unilateral purulent nasal discharge with occasional bloody discharge from the same side, the diagnosis is:

A 20-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. Nasal endoscopy shows a large polyp in the right nostril extending into the nasopharynx. His NCCT nose and PNS axial view is given. He should be managed by:
questions.solution: • The NCCT nose and PNS axial view shows the right maxillary sinus filled with mass, going to the nasal cavity and extending into the nasopharynx, suggestive of Antrochoanal polyp. Also notice the crescent of air in the nasopharynx pharyngeal wall known as Dodd/ crescent sign.

questions.text: Recurrent epistaxis is not a common feature of
questions.solution: • Nasal polyp have very poor blood supply so epistaxis does not occur in nasal polyposis

choices.text: In newborn, it presents as snuffles

questions.text: About nasal syphilis true
questions.solution: • Syphilis and some other granulomatous conditions can lead to secondary atrophic rhinitis; refer to Chapter 19 on acute and chronic rhinitis. The most common syphilis seen in the nose is tertiary syphilis

choices.text: Most common organism is Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis
Can be diagnosed by identification on biopsy

questions.text: True stamen about Rhinosporidiosis is
questions.solution:
• Rhinosporidiosis is caused by an aquatic protozoa parasite Rhinosporidium seeberi. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis id a bacteria leading to rhinoscleroma
  • The patient of Rhinosporidiosis bath in ponds frequented by animals
  • There is a red polypoid (polyp like but not true polyp. A true polyp arises because of nasal mucosal edema) mass on anterior rhinoscopy appearing loke a mulberry or strawberry with white dots (sporangia). Nasal smear or biopsy shows sporangia which is diagnostic.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common

questions.text: True about tumours of nose and PNS
questions.solution:
• The MC carcinoma of the PNS is squamous cell carcinoma
  • In people working in hardwood furniture industries the MC carcinoma is adenocarcinoma
  • Melanomas of the paranasal sinuses very rare

questions.text: Carcinoma maxillary sign stage III (T3 M0 NO), treatment of choice is
questions.solution: • For all patients of carcinoma maxillary sinus (except small T1 lesions), the treatment is surgical resection (maxillectomy) followed by radiation therapy

questions.text: Direction of nasolacrimal dust is
Maxillary sinus achieves maximum size at:

choices.text: Optic nerve and floor of orbit
Optic nerve and ethmoids air cells

questions.text: Onodi cells and Haller cells are seen in relation to:
Laryngeal crepitus is absent in the following conditions except:
questions.solution: Parapharyngeal abscess (Ref: CDT-Otolaryngology.Lalwani, 3th ed.; 460)

questions.text: Closure of glottis is by all except
questions.solution:
The posterior cricoarytenoids is the only abductor of the true vocal cords, i.e. it opens the glottis.

(Ref: Scott Brown, 8th ed., Vol 3., 889)

questions.text: Narrowest part in infant's respiratory tract is
questions.solution:
In infant's larynx the diameter of cricoid cartilage is smaller than the glottis, making subglottis the narrowest part, whereas in adults the narrowest part in the glottis.

(Ref: Scott Brown, 8th ed., Vol 1., 326)

questions.text: Tensors of vocal card are

choices.text: Two muscles adduct (close) the vocal cords
One muscle abducts (open) the vocal cords
One muscle adjusts the length of the vocal cords
One muscle adjusts the tension of the vocal cords

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding vocal cords?
questions.solution:
• All muscles of VC are adductors
  • The tensors alter the length, hence tension of vocal cords. There are two tensors of VC.

(ref. Scott Brown, 8th ed., vol 3, 889)

questions.text: Indirect laryngoscopy is primarily used to visualize:
questions.solution: ref. Dhingra, 6th ed., 384

choices.text: Thyrohyoid membrane and first tracheal ring

questions.text: The marked structures in the figure are:
questions.solution: ref: Cummings, 6th ed., 826; Scott Brown, 8th ed., Vol 3; 885

questions.text: The marked muscle is :
questions.solution:
The only intrinsic muscle lying outside the larynx.

(Ref; Cummings, 6th ed., 827)

questions.text: The function of the marked muscle is :
questions.solution:
The marked muscle is posterior cricoartytenoid

(Ref: Cummings, 6th ed., 827)

choices.text: Junction of anterior and middle 1/3rd of true vocal cords

questions.text: Site of involvement in Pachydermia larynges:
questions.solution:
• Pachydermia larynges involves the posterior commissure area.
  • Vocal nodule and vocal polyp arise at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and middle 1/3rd of true vocal cords.

(ref.,Scott Brown. 6th ed. 5/5/10)

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions is considered to be definitely precancerous in the larynx?
questions.solution:
• Rest are not precancerous.
  • Subglottic hemangiomas are benign vascular tumours. They are rare as much but can lead to progressive stridor. They are commonly associated with cutaneous hemangiomas (the most common benign skin vascular tumours in children). Most subglottic hemangiomas spontaneously resolve by 5 years of age. If large and progressive they can be excised by CO2LASER or surgically.

ref: Cummings, 6ht ed., 1609

questions.text: Which of the following is precancerous lesion?
questions.solution:
• Malignant transformation can be seen in laryngeal papillomatosis though it is rare.
  • Keratosis of larynx, i.e. leukoplakia occurs due to chronic laryngeal irritation due to smoking and is premalignant.

choices.text: Subglottis stenosis and hypopharyngeal dilatation may be seen on X-rays
Boys are more commonly affected than girls
Symptoms are predominantly caused by involvement of the supraglottis
Antibiotics do not have role in treatment

questions.text: A child presents with biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing since 2-3 days. He has fever. All of the following statements about his condition are true, except:
questions.solution:
• Fever, biphasic stridor and barking cough suggest the diagnosis to be Laryngotracheobronchitis which mainly affects the subglottis along with trachea and bronchi. The underlying cause being viral (most commonly parainfluenza ) so antibiotics have no role.
  • Rest of the options are ture. Kindly refer to text.

Ref: Cummings, 6th ed., 3048; Scott Brown, 8th ed., Vol 1, 326

questions.text: A 2(1/2) years old fully immunized child developed sore throat, dysphagia, fever and stidor in quick succession. Within 2 hours of onset of symptoms the child was very sick, pale and looked terrified. An hour later, the child became quiet and floppy. And within next one hour the child expired. The most likely diagnosis was:
questions.solution:
Since there is fever, foreign body is ruled out. Also since the child is immunized so practically no chances of diphtheria. Even if the child is immunized against Hib, the other mentioned bacteria in the text can lead to epiglottitis. Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) can also present in the same fashion but it being mainly a subglottic involvement, dysphagia is not seen here. Also in croup there is a gradual and fast development of clinical symptoms point towards the acute epiglottis.

Ref: Cummings, 6th ed., 3051; Scott Brown, 8th ed., Vol 1, 329

questions.text: Most common location of vocal nodule.
questions.solution:
The conditions involving the posterior commissure are contact ulcer, intubation granuloma and TB. Rest two locations given in the options are not specific for any condition.

ref. Cummings, 6th ed, 905; Scott Brown 8th ed, Vol 3; 951; 984

questions.text: Stridor is caused by all except:
questions.solution:
• Asthma involving small tertiary bronchi leads to wheeze.
  • Epiglottis, i.e. supraglottic laryngitis, laryngeal tumour and hypocalcaemia (causing laryngospasm) all involve larynx and can lead to stridor.

Ref, Current Diagnosis & Treatment Otolaryngology, Lalwani, 3rd ed., 481 ; Scott Brown, 8th ed., Vol 3; 1038

choices.text: Self limiting by 2-3 years of age

questions.text: About laryngomalacia all are true except:
questions.solution:
• Reassurance is all that is required
  • Supraglottoplasty is required to be done only rarely when the stridor is very severe leading to failure to thrive. Kindly refer to the text.

Ref. Current Diagnosis & Treatment Otolaryngology, Lalwani, 3rd ed., 481; Scott Brown, 8th ed., Vol 2; 333

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with gradually increasing respiratory distress since 4 days. She gives history of hospitalization and mechanical ventilation with orotracheal intubation for 2 weeks. Now she is diagnosed as having severe laryngotracheal stenosis. Next step in the management is:
questions.solution:
• Prolonged intubation has resulted in subglottic stenosis. Since it is severe, resection and end to end anastomosis is the treatment of choice. Steroids have no role.
  • LASER excision and tracheal dilation are considered in mild subglottic stenosis.

Ref. Current Diagnosis & Treatment Otolaryngology, Lalwani, 3rd ed., 487

questions.text: A 4-year-old child who was operated in infancy for tracheoesophageal fistula came with complaints of cough and expiratory wheeze. Which of the following is likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
In rest of the conditions, stridor is seen.

Ref. Current Diagnosis & Treatment Otolaryngology, Lalwani, 3rd ed., 486
